text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised text for IRM 4.26.13, Bank Secrecy Act, Structuring.
IRM 4.26.13.1 inserted new internal controls section as 4.26.13.1. This caused all other subsections to be renumbered.

ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This supersedes IRM 4.26.13 dated January 7, 2016. This material incorporates Interim Memorandum SBSE-04-0919-0046 Interim Guidance on the IRS Authority Previously Delegated Treasury Directive 15-41.
The intended audience is employees of the Bank Secrecy Act program in the Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE) division and can be referenced by all ﬁeld compliance personnel.
Table of Contents
) Purpose. This section addresses Title
Bank Secrecy Act (BSA) law and regulations as they relate to structuring. The section will assist in and of potentially structured transactions and the development of a structuring violation issue. (
) Audience. This IRM is for BSA managers, examiners and technical support personnel. (
) Policy Owner. Director, SB/SE Specialty Examination Policy. (
) Program Owner. Director, SB/SE Specialty Examination. (
) Primary Stakeholders. SB/SE Specialty Examination BSA; SB/SE ters Exam, Specialty Exam Policy BSA; Exam Quality and Technical and Chief Counsel, Division Counsel SB/SE. (
) Contact Information. To recommend changes or make any other related to this IRM section, see IRM
, Providing Feedback About an IRM Section - Outside of Clearance. (

) Program Goals. The mission of the BSA Program is to safeguard the system from the abuses of ﬁnancial crime, including terrorist ﬁnancing, laundering, and other illicit activity by providing the ﬁnancial community top quality service to help them understand their obligations under the BSA and ensure BSA compliance with integrity and fairness to all. (
) The Department of the Treasury has primary responsibility for implementing and enforcing the BSA. The Secretary of the Treasury delegated the to administer the BSA to the Director, Fi
EN.
CFR
) delegates the responsibility to the IRS to exam and ensure compliance with the requirements of
CFR Chapter X, Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, Department of the Treasury, for certain entities. (
) Director, Examination – Specialty Policy is the executive responsible for BSA Examination policy and procedures. (
) Director, Examination – Specialty Examination is the executive responsible BSA examination operational compliance. (
) Chief, BSA Policy is responsible for ensuring general information about BSA examiner responsibilities and IRM sections is communicated to and carried out by BSA examiners. (

) Reports to monitor the current year’s work plan, as well as speciﬁc are prepared and provided by Performance Planning & Analysis (PPA). reports provide Headquarters and Field Examination with timely and reliable information. There are a variety of reports designed to meet the needs of group or function. Reports used to monitor examination processes include: • Direct examination time • New examination starts • Examination closures • Average hours expended per case • No issue percentage • Closed case cycle time by workstream (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Direct examination time New examination starts Examination closures Average hours expended per case No issue percentage Closed case cycle time by

• Open case cycle time by workstream • Referrals to Examination • Referrals to Employment Tax • Referrals to CI • Number of surveyed cases • Workplan accomplishments (2) Periodic program reviews are conducted to: • Asses the effectiveness of speciﬁc programs within Examination or across the organization, • Determine if procedures are being followed, • Validate policies and procedures, and • Identify and share best/proven practices. ) Structuring is the practice of conducting ﬁnancial transactions in a speciﬁc pattern calculated to avoid the creation of certain records and reports by the Bank Secrecy Act (BSA) and/or IRC
I, Returns relating to cash received in trade or business, etc. (Form
, Report of Cash Payments $
Received in a Trade or Business) (
) Structured transactions may be discovered during: • A BSA examination • A Form
examination conducted under Title
• An income tax examination (
) Although there are many similarities between transactions structured to the BSA and IRC
I, the differences are signiﬁcant enough, so each addressed separately. (
) The examples of structuring and the methods to identify such activity presented in this IRM section and sections IRM
, Examination Tech- niques for Bank Secrecy Act Industries, and IRM
, Examination Techniques for Form
Industries, are not all inclusive. The examiner constantly be alert for new patterns. (

The deﬁnition of structuring for evading the transactions in currency reporting is found at
CFR

(xx), Structure. The elements of the structuring regulations are: • A person acting alone, in conjunction with others, or on behalf of • Conducts or attempts to conduct • One or more transactions in currency • In any amount • At one or more ﬁnancial institutions • On one or more days • In any manner • For the purpose of evading the reporting requirements of
CFR
, Filing obligations for reports of transactions in currency,
CFR
, Aggregation,
CFR
, Transactions of persons,
CFR
, Filing obligations, or
CFR
, gregation. “In any manner” includes, but is not limited to, the breaking down of a single sum of currency exceeding $
into smaller sums, including sums at or below $
, or conducting a transaction or series of currency transactions at or below $
The transaction or transactions need not exceed the $

reporting threshold at any single ﬁnancial institution or on any single day to constitute structuring within the meaning of this deﬁnition. The deﬁnition is speciﬁcally written to include those transactions that occur beyond a single business day and transactions which are conducted through more than one ﬁnancial institution, but only if the purpose of the is to evade the reporting requirements. It is not the intent of the deﬁnition to expand the reporting requirements of a ﬁnancial institution.

) The deﬁnition is speciﬁcally written to include those transactions that occur beyond a single business day and transactions which are conducted through more than one ﬁnancial institution, but only if the purpose of the transaction(s) is to evade the reporting requirements. It is not the intent of the deﬁnition to

) Structuring is illegal regardless of whether the funds are derived from legal illegal activity. The law speciﬁcally prohibits conducting a currency with a ﬁnancial institution in a way to circumvent the currency transaction reporting requirements. (

) Structuring a transaction to circumvent the reporting or recordkeeping ments along with other facts known about the underlying pattern of activity the customer, may warrant the ﬁling of a Suspicious Activity Report (SAR) the ﬁnancial institution. (

) The deﬁnition of structuring is not the same as, and is separate from, any quirement to report suspicious transactions. However, attempts to structure need to be reported as suspicious transactions on a SAR. Note: Check cashers are not generally subject to the suspicious transaction reporting requirements of the BSA but may voluntarily ﬁle a SAR. check cashing transactions are subject to the suspicious activity rules to extent that a check cashing transaction involves money transmission, orders, or traveler’s check products used in a manner to circumvent requirements. (
) Each BSA examination must include steps to identify transactions that may have been structured to avoid the reporting requirements as listed in IRM of
, Bank Secrecy Act History and Law. Structured (

) The examiner’s focus in looking for structuring during a BSA examination in a BSA be on whether the ﬁnancial institution has systems in place to detect ing or unnecessarily complex transactions, whether such systems are being implemented, and whether the ﬁnancial institution is ﬁling SARs to report tured transactions. Structured transactions may involve any number of and/or the ﬁnancial institution being examined. The BSA examination must include steps to identify if there is involvement by: a. The ﬁnancial institution acting alone for its own reasons. b. The ﬁnancial institution acting in collaboration with its customers. c. The ﬁnancial institution acting in collaboration with non-customers as laundering funds for other related or unrelated businesses). d. Employees of the ﬁnancial institution acting without the knowledge of institution and in collaboration with customers. e. Financial institutions other than the one being examined. f. Customers acting without the knowledge of the ﬁnancial institution or employees. (
) How transactions may be structured is dependent upon the speciﬁc services offered. IRM

, Examination Techniques for Bank Secrecy Act Industries, has a subsection for each industry entitled Money Laundering Trends, which includes examples of structured transactions. The examiner should review the appropriate subsections of IRM
as part of the pre- planning process and obtain an understanding of the methods that may be used to structure transactions.

, Bank Secrecy Act History and Law. The examiner’s focus in looking for structuring during a BSA examination must be on whether the ﬁnancial institution has systems in place to detect structur- ing or unnecessarily complex transactions, whether such systems are being implemented, and whether the ﬁnancial institution is ﬁling SARs to report struc- tured transactions. Structured transactions may involve any number of persons and/or the ﬁnancial institution being examined. The BSA examination must include steps to identify if there is involvement by:

a. The ﬁnancial institution acting alone for its own reasons. b. The ﬁnancial institution acting in collaboration with its customers. c. The ﬁnancial institution acting in collaboration with non-customers as laundering funds for other related or unrelated businesses). d. Employees of the ﬁnancial institution acting without the knowledge of institution and in collaboration with customers. e. Financial institutions other than the one being examined. f. Customers acting without the knowledge of the ﬁnancial institution or its employees. How transactions may be structured is dependent upon the speciﬁc ﬁnancial services offered. IRM

, Examination Techniques for Bank Secrecy Act Industries, has a subsection for each industry entitled Money Laundering Trends, which includes examples of structured transactions. The examiner should review the appropriate subsections of IRM
as part of the pre- planning process and obtain an understanding of the methods that may be used to structure transactions.
The ﬁnancial institution acting alone for its own reasons. The ﬁnancial institution acting in collaboration with its customers. The ﬁnancial institution acting in collaboration with non

customers (such as laundering funds for other related or unrelated businesses). Employees of the ﬁnancial institution acting without the knowledge of institution and in collaboration with customers. Financial institutions other than the one being examined. Customers acting without the knowledge of the ﬁnancial institution or its employees.
How transactions may be structured is dependent upon the speciﬁc ﬁnancial services offered. IRM

, Examination Techniques for Bank Secrecy Act Industries, has a subsection for each industry entitled Money Laundering Trends, which includes examples of structured transactions. The examiner should review the appropriate subsections of IRM
as part of the pre- planning process and obtain an understanding of the methods that may be used to structure transactions.
Consistently make deposits of currency into a bank account below $
when available currency is greater than $
Make currency deposits into multiple bank accounts, at multiple institutions, all less than $
but aggregating to greater than $
, so, no ﬁnancial institution is required to make a report. Cash a check greater than $
for a customer, provide currency than $
on that day and direct the customer to return the following day for the remainder of the currency. Direct a customer wishing to conduct a wire transmittal of greater than $
to conduct an immediate transaction of less than $
and return the following day to make a second transaction. Structure a reportable customer transaction so, it is below the reporting threshold without the customer’s knowledge.
Examine the institution’s BSA AML program and its implementation. All elements of an AML program, as mandated by
CFR Part
, Rules For Banks,
CFR Part
, Rules for Casinos and Card Clubs,
CFR Part
, Rules for Money Service Businesses,
CFR Part
, Rules for Insurance Companies, and
CFR Part
, Rules for Dealers in Precious Metals, Precious Stones, or Jewels, (PMSJ) must be examined. The details of such an examination are discussed in IRM
, Bank Secrecy Act

a. Check speciﬁcally for the presence of a monitoring methodology to structuring. If a methodology is in place, evaluate its effectiveness against your own testing. b. Analyze the headquarter’s monitoring system to determine if transactions for all agent and branch locations are analyzed to identify customers going from location to location to circumvent the BSA requirements. c. Examine potentially structured transactions that have been identiﬁed by the monitoring methodology. The presence or indication of structuring is undetected by the ﬁnancial institution, despite the presence of an AML program with all the required elements, may indicate a weakness in the program. Note: While the presence of a functional monitoring methodology is not and of itself sufficient to verify the absence of structuring, the presence of a sound monitoring program can lead to a determina

tion that, from a risk evaluation viewpoint, participation by the ﬁnancial institution in structuring may be less likely. Conversely, the absence of a monitoring methodology may be an indication of an environment where structuring is likely.
While the presence of a functional monitoring methodology is not in and of itself sufficient to verify the absence of structuring, the presence of a sound monitoring program can lead to a determina

tion that, from a risk evaluation viewpoint, participation by the ﬁnancial institution in structuring may be less likely. Conversely, the absence of a monitoring methodology may be an indication of an environment where structuring is likely.

) Determine if the ﬁnancial institution has a monitoring system in place to any unusually complex transactions using multiple ﬁnancial services. a. Does the monitoring system identify these transactions at the point of sale? A customer may seek to move funds by wiring a portion and pur- chasing money orders or travelers’ checks for the balance.

(

) Review voided transactions to ensure the transactions were cancelled and merely voided in the accounting records and a subsequent transaction conducted right below BSA recordkeeping or reporting requirements. This be accomplished by tracing voids to any records prepared by third parties, such as issuers of money orders and travelers’ checks. (

or (

) Eliminate legitimate reasons for the pattern in which deposits are made. For example, if the ﬁnancial institution’s insurance policy limits the coverage on amount of currency which may be retained at the store; multiple deposits be made during one day to remain below this threshold. (

Also compare the volume of services. Does the increase in volume correlate to know growth in the business? Is it consistent with other business in the area and with the known customer (

) To successfully structure a series of transactions, the customer may: a. Obtain the cooperation of the owners of the ﬁnancial institution. b. Obtain the cooperation of an employee. Internal Revenue Manual

If not, how do they compare the activity of one ﬁnancial service (such as, money transmission) against another to look for unusual activity conducted within a relatively short period of time? If no monitoring system exists, consider requesting and evaluating data within a time frame that will allow the examiner to compare transactions for different services offered by a ﬁnancial institution at the same location, or in a headquarters’ examination, at locations in close physical proximity.

a. Has the ﬁnancial institution or customer broken down the transaction into smaller transactions? b. Determine whether any ﬁnancial transactions are being regularly made to owners and/or employees. d. Transaction testing should identify any potentially structured transactions. The unusual activity should be provided to the MSB to determine if they made an initial identiﬁcation of the activity and their decision process as to whether the transaction or pattern of transactions was conducted to circumvent BSA requirements.
Analyze the pattern in which currency is deposited into all bank accounts. Does the ﬁnancial institution consistently make deposits at $10,000 or
To successfully structure a series of transactions, the customer may:
requirements. Conduct transactions at multiple agents of a larger ﬁnancial institution. (An individual may go to multiple money transmitter locations that happen to be agents for the same company)
Note: This is called “perfect” structuring because while the total of the transactions exceeds $
, the total amount transacted at ﬁnancial institution on a single business day is under $
Thus, no ﬁnancial institution had a duty to ﬁle a CTR. g. Conduct numerous small transactions over several days. (

) There is a balance between the need to disguise the transaction and the to move large sums of funds inherent in any structuring enterprise. Fees that are charged for the transaction, the time involved in handling small transac- tions, the potential need to involve others, and the need to place the transactions with more than one ﬁnancial institution to remain anonymous, all work against the customer seeking to structure transactions. However, the relative lack of sophisticated compliance systems compared to depository ﬁnancial institutions and the lack of a requirement to “know your customer” made MSBs an attractive vehicle through which individuals structure funds. (

) Various examination methods can and should be employed to detect structur- ing by customers. All the methods described in the subsections below should be utilized, if possible. The examiner should always be prepared to adjust the examination plan to consider any method that would assist in revealing struc- tured transactions. (

) One method is to analyze transactions at risk-based thresholds. These olds are determined by considering these factors: a. What is the largest transaction amount that can be conducted without requiring identiﬁcation of the customer? The need for anonymity will cause the customer to consider the thresholds that trigger a ing requirement for the ﬁnancial institution. Many ﬁnancial institutions have established lower thresholds to mitigate their risk by securing the identiﬁcation of customers conducting smaller, more frequent which may indicate structuring. The major money transmitter companies require identiﬁcation at amounts well below $
Although their only BSA requirement is to secure proper identiﬁcation to ﬁle an accurate CTR, check cashers will often establish controls well below $
as part of their internal risk management. b. What is the impact of the maximum face value of a single transaction? the maximum value of a single money order is $
, consider how

The need for anonymity will cause the customer to consider the thresholds that trigger a recordkeep- ing requirement for the ﬁnancial institution. What is the impact of the maximum face value of a single transaction? If the maximum value of a single money order is $500, consider how many

money orders may be purchased at one time and remain below the iden- tiﬁcation requirement. Some ﬁnancial institutions may establish dollar limits on the amount of transactions they will allow a customer to conduct within one business day. For example, wire companies may establish

money orders may be purchased at one time and remain below the iden- tiﬁcation requirement. Some ﬁnancial institutions may establish dollar limits on the amount of transactions they will allow a customer to conduct within one business day. For example, wire companies may establish limits or require additional information as to the source of funds and business purpose for non-traditional transactions. A major retailer may set a limit for the purchase of money orders at $

to reduce their risk of failing to secure the identiﬁcation required by the regulations. While such limits appear to eliminate reportable transactions or recordkeeping re- quirements, they simply require the customer to be more sophisticated in the methods employed to circumvent these limits. These lower limits may require added due diligence by the ﬁnancial institution when identifying suspicious activity. The examiner should be especially alert to the potential use of agents or nominees in these situations. What does the institution consider to be the average transaction size per individual transaction for each category of service offered? The examiner should do a trend analysis on the data sample to see if there are signiﬁ- cant variations in the average transaction sizes. This can lead to indications of structuring. method is to eliminate legitimate activities from the scope of records to examined. Most activity through a ﬁnancial institution is legitimate. During
business purpose for non-traditional transactions. A major retailer may set a limit for the purchase of money orders at $

to reduce their risk of failing to secure the identiﬁcation required by the regulations. While such limits appear to eliminate reportable transactions or recordkeeping re- quirements, they simply require the customer to be more sophisticated in the methods employed to circumvent these limits. These lower limits may require added due diligence by the ﬁnancial institution when identifying suspicious activity. The examiner should be especially alert to the potential use of agents or nominees in these situations. c. What does the institution consider to be the average transaction size per individual transaction for each category of service offered? The examiner should do a trend analysis on the data sample to see if there are signiﬁ- cant variations in the average transaction sizes. This can lead to indications of structuring. (

) Another method is to eliminate legitimate activities from the scope of records to be examined. Most activity through a ﬁnancial institution is legitimate. During the initial interview, the examiner should determine what transactions could be eliminated from the scope of the examination. Consider legitimate transactions either by amount, characteristics, range of transaction values, and the frequency of customer activity within a day as well as over time. For example: a. Who is the primary customer of a check casher? If the primary customers are presenting payroll checks, then it should be possible to eliminate checks with odd dollar amounts (because of withholding) and at a certain maximum amount. If the primary customers are presenting government assistance checks, there is a pattern present in both the amounts and when these are presented that should make it possible to eliminate them. b. What is an average family to family value range of wire transfer? Most wire transfers are for family support. Relatives in the United States work and send money back to their home country for the support of their family. Most wire transmitter companies know what the average family member to family member transaction is. Is it possible to proﬁle legiti- mate activity and exclude it from the examination? Money transmitter companies will often plan with other businesses, such as utility companies and cable companies, where they will collect their customer payments and transmit these funds to them daily. Is it possible to exclude these transactions? c. What is the average number and dollar range of money orders purchased by customers who are using money orders as replacements for checks? d. What is the average amount of travelers’ checks sold to a typical customer? e. Were there any “specials” being offered by the ﬁnancial institution which may be the motive for what appears to be structured transactions? For example, for a two-week period a wire remitter is offering a special rate of $
to wire funds below $
A customer needs to wire transmit $
and the regular fee would be $
The customer breaks up the transaction by conducting three $
transfers at a total cost of $
The customer is structuring the transactions to save $
, not to circum- vent the BSA requirements.

) Another method is to eliminate legitimate activities from the scope of records to be examined. Most activity through a ﬁnancial institution is legitimate. During the initial interview, the examiner should determine what transactions could be eliminated from the scope of the examination. Consider legitimate transactions either by amount, characteristics, range of transaction values, and the frequency of customer activity within a day as well as over time. For example:

Another method is to eliminate legitimate activities from the scope of records to be examined. Most activity through a ﬁnancial institution is legitimate. During the initial interview, the examiner should determine what transactions could be eliminated from the scope of the examination. Consider legitimate transactions either by amount, characteristics, range of transaction values, and the frequency of customer activity within a day as well as over time. For example:

a. Who is the primary customer of a check casher? If the primary are presenting payroll checks, then it should be possible to eliminate checks with odd dollar amounts (because of withholding) and at a maximum amount. If the primary customers are presenting assistance checks, there is a pattern present in both the amounts and when these are presented that should make it possible to eliminate b. What is an average family to family value range of wire transfer? Most wire transfers are for family support. Relatives in the United States and send money back to their home country for the support of their family. Most wire transmitter companies know what the average family member to family member transaction is. Is it possible to proﬁle legiti- mate activity and exclude it from the examination? Money transmitter companies will often plan with other businesses, such as utility companies and cable companies, where they will collect their payments and transmit these funds to them daily. Is it possible to these transactions? c. What is the average number and dollar range of money orders by customers who are using money orders as replacements for d. What is the average amount of travelers’ checks sold to a typical customer? e. Were there any “specials” being offered by the ﬁnancial institution may be the motive for what appears to be structured transactions? ) The safety of the employee conducting a structuring interview is a factor in considering the location of the interview. Interviews of customers should be held in an IRS office. (

) The examiner must consider the following: • Who has knowledge of the transactions? • What are the potential violation(s)? • What are the elements of the violation(s) that must be proven? • What records are available to prove the violation(s)? • Who is in possession of those records? • How will those records be obtained? • Who must be interviewed to explain those records? • Can a pattern be identiﬁed in the transactions to support a tion that it is an ongoing activity? • What is the total value of all structured transactions? To make a proper determination, certain information must be obtained from the interview; however, the initial interview questions need to focus on determining whether the ﬁnancial institution, an employee, or a customer is responsible for the unusual or complex transaction which initially indicated structuring.

• What are the circumstances behind the transactions? • Were sufficient funds initially available to conduct a series of transac- tions which would constitute an apparent violation (for example, the $

reporting threshold for reporting)? It is necessary to show that the transaction could have been conducted as a single and the person took actions to break it up to avoid a currency tion report. • When did these transactions initially begin? • How often were these types of transactions conducted? • Did anyone else conduct transactions on their behalf? • If the person admits that transactions are structured, for what purpose were they structured? • What was the source or likely source of the funds used? Are they a legal source? In some instances (especially if funds are derived a criminal source), it may only be possible to eliminate legitimate sources and by inference conclude that the remaining sources are illegal. • What is the person’s knowledge of the BSA? Examiners should try to put the person being interviewed at ease when dis-

Bank Secrecy did, the source of the funds, and the business purpose for the transactions, should the examiner ask about knowledge of the BSA. Asking about knowledge of the BSA initially may make the person defensive and less to provide a complete explanation of the activity. (

) When a ﬁnancial institution’s owners or officers are the subject of the ing interview, knowledge of the BSA requirements should have been established in the initial interview. The examiner should have determined, through a series of open-ended questions, the extent of the subject’s knowledge of the law. While the subject may have shown knowledge during prior visit(s), the examiner should be prepared to address the subject’s lack recall of the BSA as a possible defense. (

) After the examiner has interviewed the owners/officers as to the speciﬁcs of the potentially structured transactions, the examiner may need to ask addi- tional questions to clarify their knowledge of the BSA requirements, including tying down their knowledge of what structuring is. (

) If the subject of the interview is an employee, knowledge of the BSA require- ments may be determined from reviewing training material and records the ﬁnancial institution’s AML program requirements. Additional interviewing may be required to determine the overall understanding of the BSA require- ments and knowledge of the background of the transactions. (

) If the subject of the interview is a customer, the interview should be limited determining whether the ﬁnancial institution provided guidance on structuring transactions to circumvent the BSA requirements. (

, tit. iv) that the government needs only to show that the transactor knew that there was a BSA reporting requirement but did not need to show that the knew that structuring was illegal. The law was enacted after the Supreme Court decision in Ratzlaff v. United States (

) The examiner should establish the subject’s knowledge of the BSA through series of open-ended questions. The examiner should also establish that the subject had such knowledge at the time the transaction(s) occurred. of open-ended questions are: • What do you know about currency transaction reports? • When did you acquire this knowledge? • Who told you and what were the circumstances? • What do you believe the law says about breaking a transaction into smaller amounts to avoid the currency report? ) The presence or indication of structuring that is undetected by the ﬁnancial stitution, despite the presence of an AML program with all the required elements, may indicate a weakness in the program. (

) A structuring violation on the ﬁnancial institution should be pursued only if results of the interview establish that all the following were true: a. The transactions, either the ﬁnancial institution’s own transactions or its customer’s, were structured to avoid a currency transaction report. b. The person(s) involved had knowledge of the BSA. c. No legitimate purpose existed for structuring the transaction(s). d. The amounts involved are material. (
) If you have established all of the elements as listed above, a referral for potential civil enforcement should be considered on Form
, Report of Apparent Violation of Financial Recordkeeping and Reporting Regulations, or referral for possible criminal investigation should be made using Form
, Referral Report of Potential Criminal Fraud Cases, as appropriate. See IRM
, Special Procedures. (

In setting the scope and depth of a Form 8300 examination, several factors should be considered:

To determine the threshold amount of customer payments to be reviewed, consider what number of payments is normally made in a single transaction for the speciﬁc industry. For example, if customers make an initial payment, a ﬁnancing payment, and the balance of the down payment, then the expected number of payments is three. Adjust the threshold to identify three payments, which total more than To detect the potential involvement of owners/officers and employees when recording the transaction for later analysis, also record the names of employees involved.

) It is as important to consider all legitimate reasons for the method of payments as it is to pursue those that support a structuring violation. Absent additional facts, such as active assistance by the ﬁrm to structure the transaction, the essential determination to be made is whether the ﬁrm or the customer caused the method(s) of payment. in currency and the balance is paid as indicated.
EXPLANATION
Below market rate plans are marketing tools. The plans normally restrict both the length of the contract and the amount available for ﬁnancing. Absent other facts, such a transaction is not struc
tured.

Some credit card plans offer incentives, such as air miles, for use of the card. There are normally restrictions on the total amount available for the incentives. Absent other facts such a transaction not structured.

The customer wanted to see what it would be like to have such a large amount of currency on hand. The customer may have been seeking to limit the amount to be spent and the business made additional sales beyond that limit. The customer is from out of town and did not think a personal check would be accepted, but had a general idea as to the total cost. other facts such transactions are not

) If the subject of the structuring interview is an employee or customer and it is determined that the trade or business is not involved, examiners should ﬁrst consider whether a referral to IRS Criminal Investigation (CI) is warranted. If not, the relevant information concerning the customer or employee should be copied and a separate case ﬁle should be prepared. The separate case ﬁle should be completed following the guidance at IRM
